instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON â€“ CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7052: What is R7052? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message:
Hello

This Board has no sign of water damage.
When it's plugged in the fan spins for 1 sec, stops for 3 sec and keeps repeating that process.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is good
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.5v

What can be causing this fanspin?

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message: meassured at l7550 and there is a short to ground

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message: 3,4,6,7,8 on <TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR> shorted

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message:
I bet L7550 is just the normal low resistance of about 2-3 Ohm.

Is voltage also coming high on L7510 when fan spins?

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message:
L7550 is about 0,1 ohm
voltage is 0 all the time at both L7510 and L7550

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message:
Check <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>, especially pin 2 for corrosion and measure 90K.
Did you measure over L7550 or L7550 to GND?

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message:
measured over.
diode mode L7510 and L7550 is 0.015 on both
<RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> is ok but pin 2 on <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> does look a bit worse than the other pins.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message:
Why would you measure over a coil? Resistance to GND is the one that matters.
Measure <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> by measuring from F7040 to pin 2 on <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>, this way you ensure that there are no corroded traces.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message: it measures 91k

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message:
So what is resistance to GND on L7550 and L7510?
Does <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> come high when the fan spins?

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> goes from 0v to about 3v when fan spins
resistans to ground on both coils is 0.015

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message: 0.015 in Ohm or diode mode? 0.015 is way too low, compare it with another board. Boards I have here measure between 5-13 Ohm.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message: yes, it's to low. I wrote that in my second and third post in this thread. Or is it not a short to ground when it measures that low?

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message: 0.015 Ohm to GND is too low. Nothing more I can say. Compare it to some working boards, but the ones I have here are 5 Ohm minimum. It would most likely be a shorted CPU as it is on 2 different busses.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message:
hi
I think I have problems with understanding how to measure things.
I measured L7550 and L7510 in diode mode, red on ground black on coil, and got 0.013
If i measure ohm on my fluke between coil and ground i get 10.9 on L7550 and L7510

My other board, with no image; measures 10.7 on L7550 and 9.6 on L7510

Sorry if i'm stupid but i'm trying to learn this!!!

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message: OK, voltage on both pins of Y2805 when fans spins?

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message:
it's a bit hard to see but 0,9 volt on both pins.
the "no image" board is 0.97 volt

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message: That is all ok. Running our of ideas here too. You say <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> does look corroded, are you able to take a picture? I'm pretty sure it will be corrosion somewhere. Any history on this board?

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message:
I bought the mbp for 50$ with no other information from The seller than that it wouldn't start. 
<RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> doesn't look corroded. It's the pin on <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> that it's attached to that was corroded.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message:
Well I would think it has been a liquid spill then. Look closer for corrosion.
Also what voltage are you getting on both sides of <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message:
I get 12.6 volt on both sides. It was only that pin on <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> that looked bad. But almost all joints around <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> look a bit poorly soldered. There are many pads that doesn,t hav solder up on the side on the chip. 

Can the problem be caused by a bad <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>. Should i try to replace it?

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message:
It could, but I have never seen <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> fail. Lets say 5% chance......
I would suspect something wring with SPI ROM first. Measure all pins of it on diode mode and compare to working board.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message: same numbers on SPI ROM on both boards.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message: all S0 and S3 rails goes high when fan spin

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message: I am out of ideas on this one. Most likely corrosion somewhere. If you can take HiRes close up pictures of the board I can have a look..

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message:
I Would try replace the SPI with one from a donor <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board. You dont need to worry about ME region on 2011 years so you can just pull the EFI of a donor board with no reprogramming.

You also need to inspect <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>. <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> drives the clock signal for the PCH and therefore is important when looking at quarter fan spin.

Check <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> and all corresponding traces. This is current sensing for the battery and can sometimes cause quarter fan spin symtoms. After doing all of the above you are looking at a failed PCH.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins 2 sec
threads.message: You most definitely need to worry about the ME! For testing it does not matter but it does cause issues.
